WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The kanji two and the radical two are the exact same things. Therefore, you know the kanji for two already!
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: More simply put, you can just know that this kanji is the double of One. It's two lines, that's not all that hard to remember!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: Think of all the things you have Two of. What is the most important? Some would say eyes, some would say ears. I would say the knee („Å´) because if you didn't have them, it'd be really hard to go up stairs.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine yourself without two knees, and see what it would be like. What would give you trouble? What couldn't you do? Just imagining this for a minute or two will help you to remember the reading of this kanji more effectively.
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: Two horizontal strokes representing the one plus one equals two.
origin_of_ch_char_book: Before the invention of Hanzi (Chinese characters), the Chinese used knots (rope) or simple symbols. As the society became more complex, the need for more efficient ways for communication were needed. Hanzi (Chinese characters) were developed to meet such needs. What did the early writers think to express number ‚Äúone‚Äù? As children use their fingers to count, the ancient people used twigs and sticks to express numbers and to count. A twig (‰∏Ä, yi, one), two twigs (‰∫å, er, two), three twings (‰∏â, san, three) four twigs (Âõõ, si=ssu, four) became the letters from 1 to 4. Branches used for telling fortunes or for calculation (14th-19th century) However, ‚Äúone‚Äù ‰∏Ä (yi, one) does not simply mean the number one in the numerical sense. In AD 100, a Chinese scholar wrote a book ‚ÄúShuo Wen Jie Zi‚Äù which provides many explanations behind Hanzi. Among over 9,000 Hanzi characters in this book, the ‚Äúone (‰∏Ä)‚Äù is explained first as followed: ‚ÄúIn the beginning there was only One Way, and this Way divided earth from heaven and made everything.‚Äù As we can see, ‚Äúone‚Äù is not just a simple tree twig. It is also philosophically understood as the ‚Äúsole principle‚Äù from which heaven, earth and living things originate d from.,The represent of a village is reading a written prayer to God in the early 20th century The character Á¨¨ (di, auxiliary word for ordinal numbers) is also from this character under the same logic. The top of this character means bamboo (Á´π), the material of spear, and below is the rope which winds the spear. For example, Á¨¨‰∏Ä (di yi) means ‚Äòthe first‚Äô (the first rope of the spear), Á¨¨‰∫å (di er) means ‚Äòthe second‚Äô.
humanum_full_description_en:
Elaboration: The product of two is drawn as a number, which means the number two. The two characters of "‰∫å" are of equal length, which is different from the characters of "‰∏ä" and "‰∏ã".

The word " two " in oracle bone inscriptions is used as a numeral, which can indicate the cardinal number (the number of things), such as "Collection" 22048: "Niu Er." It can also indicate an ordinal number, that is, "second", such as "Collection" 3246: "‰ªä‰∫å" Moon." The word " two " is often used in oracle bone inscriptions, such as "erfang" as the name of the country and "ersi" as the object of sacrifice.

The word " two " in the bronze inscriptions is also used as a numeral, such as the Five Sacrifice Wei Ding: "Yu Xi (Zhao) Da (Tai) Room Dong Ni (Suo) Ying Er Chuan." It refers to the two management and management of the northeastern part of Yu Zhao's Tai Family. River. Another example is „ù¨Á∞ã: "Èöπ(only) Wang Shiyou (have) two sacrifices." The ancients used one sacrifice to represent a year, so " two " here is also used as a numeral.

"Said Wen": "Two, the number of the earth, from even one. All the two belong to from two. Bie, the ancient text two." According to the inscription " two ", there are " two " from " ge " from " " Bei " is written in the form of " Ge " and " Two " in the latter province. Since many ancient Chinese characters mistaken " Ge " for " Yi ", the ancient texts collected in "Shuowen" are from " Yi " to " Second ". See " II " for details.

The word " two" in oracle bone inscriptions is used as a numeral, which can indicate the cardinal number (the number of things), such as "Collection" 22048: "Niu Er." It can also indicate an ordinal number, that is, "second", such as "Collection" 3246: "‰ªä‰∫å" Moon." The word " two" is often used in oracle bone inscriptions, such as "erfang" as the name of the country and "ersi" as the object of sacrifice. The word " two" in the bronze inscriptions is also used as a numeral, such as the Five Sacrifice Wei Ding: "Yu Xi (Zhao) Da (Tai) Room Dong Ni (Suo) Ying Er Chuan." Radicals: ‰∫å  (two)
Meaning Mnemonic
The kanji two and the radical two are the exact same things. Therefore, you know the kanji for two already!
More simply put, you can just know that this kanji is the double of One. It's two lines, that's not all that hard to remember!
Reading Mnemonic
Think of all the things you have Two of. What is the most important? Some would say eyes, some would say ears. I would say the knee („Å´) because if you didn't have them, it'd be really hard to go up stairs.
Imagine yourself without two knees, and see what it would be like. What would give you trouble? What couldn't you do? Just imagining this for a minute or two will help you to remember the reading of this kanji more effectively.
